scenario_3_emergency.message: I am the patient, my name is David Brown
How would you prefer us to keep in touch with you? We can contact you via email, text message (SMS), phone call, or continue through this chat.
email me please
Alright David, and just to confirm your details, could I please have your date of birth?
Alright David, could I please confirm your NHS number for our records?
Alright Mr. Brown, just to confirm, could I please have your phone number for our records?
Alright Mr. Brown, could you please provide me with the name of your GP?
Dr. Smith

Thank you, David Brown! I've collected all the information we need. We've noted your preference to be contacted via email. You'll now be connected with our clinical team for your pre-consultation assessment.
Thank you for completing your registration. I'm now going to ask you some clinical questions to prepare for your consultation. Let's start — what is the main reason for your visit today?
I have liver cirrhosis. Severe abdominal pain, level 7. History of ascites.

Given your cirrhosis and ascites history, and the severity of your abdominal pain (7/10), have you noticed any new or worsening jaundice (yellowing of the skin or eyes), confusion, vomiting blood, or black, tarry stools? These can be signs of serious complications.
I take propranolol 40mg and spironolactone 100mg daily.
When did this abdominal pain start, and has it been gradually worsening, or did it come on suddenly? Also, can you describe the pain – is it sharp, cramping, constant, or something else?
No known allergies. I've cut down drinking to once a week.

Do you have any recent lab results, radiology reports, referral letters, or NHS app screenshots to share? These help us assess your case more accurately. You can upload them now, or type 'skip' if you don't have any.
The pain has been getting worse. Sometimes I see blood in my stool.
Your clinical assessment is now complete. Based on the information gathered, your case has been assessed as HIGH priority. Our booking team will now arrange your consultation appointment.

Based on your HIGH risk assessment, we need to book your consultation within 2 days. Here are the available appointments:

  1. 2026-03-02 at 09:00 with Dr. Available
  2. 2026-03-02 at 10:00 with Dr. Available
  3. 2026-03-02 at 11:00 with Dr. Available

Please reply with the number of your preferred slot (1, 2, or 3).

Your appointment has been confirmed!

Date: 2026-03-02
Time: 09:00
Provider: Dr. Available
Appointment ID: APT-PT-1771936131-S03-2026-03-02

Pre-appointment instructions:
  - Please bring a valid photo ID and your NHS card
  - Arrive 15 minutes before your appointment time
  - Avoid alcohol completely for at least 48 hours before your appointment
  - If you are on a low-sodium diet, please continue following it
  - Fasting is required for 8-12 hours before your appointment (water is fine)
  - A blood test may be required — please wear comfortable clothing with easy access to your arm
  - Please remind the clinician of your allergies: No known allergies
  - If you experience any worsening symptoms before your appointment, please contact NHS 111 or attend A&E
  - Bring any recent lab results, imaging reports, or medication lists that you haven't already shared with us

We'll keep in touch before your appointment to check on you.
I've noticed some swelling in my legs and ankles

I'm sorry to hear you're not feeling well, David Brown. I need to ask you a few quick questions so our clinical team can properly assess the situation.

Besides the swelling in your legs and ankles, which started when and has it worsened, are you experiencing any shortness of breath, abdominal pain or distension, or difficulty doing your usual daily activities? On a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being hardly noticeable and 10 being the worst swelling you can imagine, how would you rate the swelling?
It started about 3 days ago and it's getting worse each day

Given that the swelling in your legs and ankles has been worsening over the past three days, could you please rate the severity of the swelling *right now* on a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 is hardly noticeable and 10 is the most severe swelling you can imagine?
Yes, I also have some abdominal swelling and I feel more tired
On a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 is barely noticeable and 10 is the most severe abdominal swelling you can imagine, how would you rate your abdominal swelling *right now*?
I'd say about 6 out of 10. I can still walk but it's uncomfortable

Thank you for answering those questions. Based on your responses, your symptoms need urgent clinical attention. Our clinical team has been notified and will review your case as a priority. We will contact you about bringing your appointment forward.

In the meantime: Please contact the clinic immediately to arrange for an urgent appointment. Monitor your symptoms closely, especially any changes in breathing or increased abdominal pain. Follow any existing dietary restrictions for cirrhosis.

scenario_6_complex_clinical.message: Hello, I'm filling in for my father. I'm his daughter.

His name is Harold Wilson. Call him please.
And to confirm Mr. Wilson's details, could I please have his date of birth?
Okay, and could you please provide me with Mr. Wilson's NHS number?

Okay, great! And to help us update Mr. Wilson's records, could you please provide the name of his GP?
Dr. Liver

Thank you, Harold Wilson! I've collected all the information we need. We've noted your preference to be contacted via phone. You'll now be connected with our clinical team for your pre-consultation assessment.
He has liver cirrhosis with ascites and portal hypertension. Pain level 7 out of 10. Severe abdominal swelling.
I see you're dealing with cirrhosis. Can you tell me what's been bothering you the most today?
He takes propranolol 40mg, spironolactone 100mg, lactulose 15ml three times daily, rifaximin 550mg twice daily, metformin 500mg, and warfarin 5mg.
You mentioned you're dealing with cirrhosis. Can you tell me what's been going on that made you reach out today?
He's allergic to penicillin which causes anaphylaxis, and allergic to codeine which causes nausea.
You mentioned you're dealing with cirrhosis. Can you tell me what's bothering you most today?
The pain has been worse for 2 weeks. His ankles are very swollen. He stopped drinking 3 years ago.
